awd_titl_txt: The Mathematical Inquiry Project: Faculty Instructional Change for Enhanced Student Learning and Success in Entry-Level Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Policymakers, professional organizations, and educational researchers have cited the importance of widespread adoption of inquiry-oriented, student-centered instruction across all levels of undergraduate mathematics. The Mathematical Inquiry Project (MIP) at Oklahoma State University aims to achieve that goal by fostering a statewide collaboration among mathematics departments at the 27 public institutions of higher education in Oklahoma.  The MIP focuses on increasing the use of three elements of mathematical inquiry: active learning techniques, incorporation of meaningful applications of mathematics, and development of academic success skills.  To achieve this transformative change in undergraduate mathematics instruction, the project will develop a community of practice to provide the needed professional support, mentoring, instructional activity development, and community development. By fostering sustainable, effective implementation of mathematical inquiry at large scale in Oklahoma, the MIP aims to enhance the effectiveness of hundreds of mathematics faculty and improve the learning of thousands of entry-level mathematics students across the state. 

To achieve its goals, the MIP will conduct Initiation Workshops to prioritize the concepts and skills for College Algebra/Precalculus, Quantitative Reasoning, Modeling, Calculus 1, and Academic Success Skills. Following these workshops, Collaborative Research and Development teams will develop instructional modules for each of the priority topics defined by the Initiation Workshops. Subsequently, Regional Workshops, led by the members of the relevant Collaborative Research and Development team, will help faculty learn to how to use these modules in their courses and provide continuing peer mentoring during implementation of the instructional modules.  Throughout the project, project personnel will examine the evolution of the MIP community of practice, the evolution of individual faculty, and the impact of MIP on student success.  This analysis will be used to produce a refined model for developing and sustaining an effective system-wide faculty community of practice.  The MIP model for building a community of practice around inquiry-oriented mathematics, refined through the project research and evaluation, can inform mathematics faculty professional development and mentoring throughout the nation, potentially exerting a transformative impact on undergraduate mathematics teaching and learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview 

The Mathematical Inquiry Project (MIP) is a statewide collaboration among mathematics departments at institutions of higher education in Oklahoma to improve student success in entry-level college mathematics courses. The project builds on previous reforms that (a) have offered general education mathematics options that are applicable to students’ certificate and degree programs, and (b) have provided support for all students to succeed in these credit-bearing courses. The MIP has directly supported over 200 college mathematics faculty in Oklahoma to

  1. increase use of active learning techniques,

  2. incorporate meaningful applications, and

  3. attend to broader academic success skills.

These faculty have further provided leadership at their institutions to develop and share instructional resources, mentor other faculty, and conduct research to inform continued improvement.

 

Intellectual Merit

The MIP empowers mathematics faculty to develop the expertise necessary to incorporate theory, research, and policy recommendations to design and implement effective student inquiry in mathematics courses. The MIP also supports this broad base of faculty leaders to then disseminate these resources and foster effective implementation at scale.

The MIP initiated faculty collaboration on instructional design and implementation with a series of five Initiation Workshops (each a week in duration) to prioritize the concepts and skills for College Algebra/Precalculus, Quantitative Reasoning, Modeling, Calculus 1, and general Academic Success Skills. Participating faculty then produced workshop reports detailing the consensus priorities for all subsequent work supported by the MIP, available at https://okmip.com/initiation-workshops/.

The MIP supported 61 Collaborative Research and Development teams of faculty to develop instructional modules for the priority topics identified by the Initiation Workshops. Faculty teams submitted proposals for resource development addressing at least one of the areas identified by the Initiation Workshop reports. Authors of successful proposals developed modules providing instructional resources to be implemented across multiple class sessions to support development of critical core concepts for the course. These resources were then submitted for blind peer-review with opportunities to revise and resubmit based on those reviews. After a successful review, all final resources developed by faculty collaborations were published on the project website at https://okmip.com/publications/.

The MIP fostered broader-scale faculty development by supporting the emerging leaders to conduct single-day Regional Workshops for other faculty at local institutions. The MIP convened multiple summits and online meetings for these statewide faculty leaders to monitor ongoing progress of the project and to advise and support future work.

The MIP research team has been investigating the nature of change and faculty leadership emerging throughout the project, the implementation of the project modules, and the impacts on student success. Throughout all MIP participation opportunities, faculty participants were asked to provide information on their goals for participation, priorities for inquiry-oriented instruction in entry-level college math classes, interpretation and operationalization of active learning, meaningful applications, and academic success skills, and their role as a leader in institutional and state level reform. Throughout the project, we observed a large increase in faculty confidence in advancing their own ideas for instructional reform and to produce and share resources for other faculty to use. Participating faculty have established strong professional relationships with others - not only at their institution, but across the state - and are able to reach out to this community when they make program and instructional decisions. They express that they leverage these connections to address statewide issues such as student success in transfer, applicability of courses across degree programs, and statewide adoption, alignment and implementation of entry-level math pathways.

 

Broader Impacts

By fostering sustainable, effective implementation of mathematical inquiry at large scale in Oklahoma, the MIP conveys the benefits of active learning, meaningful applications, and broader academic success skills to hundreds of mathematics faculty and thousands of entry-level mathematics students. These reforms have been shown to be disproportionately effective for underrepresented groups in academic degree attainment, and thus have potential to significantly reduce gender, ethnic, and socio-economic gaps. The MIP capitalizes on prior state reform efforts to focus on gateway mathematics courses that are critical for success across all degree programs, and thus addresses imperative reforms for college completion and future economic mobility. The key aspects of mathematical inquiry addressed by the MIP play a crucial role in the development of a more broadly quantitatively literate society by providing practical, flexible quantitative problem-solving skills. The MIP also makes instructional materials for mathematical inquiry and corresponding instructor supports freely available to college and university faculty.
